visuals.title: Voltage Amplifier: Thévenin Model
visuals.description: The voltage amplifier has Thévenin equivalent output: V_out = A_V · V_in. Ideal: R_in → ∞, R_out → 0.

visuals.title: Current Amplifier: Norton Model
visuals.description: The current amplifier has Norton equivalent output: I_out = A_I · I_in. Ideal: R_in → 0, R_out → ∞.

visuals.title: Transconductance Amplifier: V_in → I_out
visuals.description: Output current proportional to input voltage. Gain G_M has units of Siemens (1/Ω). Ideal: R_in → ∞, R_out → ∞.

visuals.title: Transresistance Amplifier: I_in → V_out
visuals.description: Output voltage proportional to input current. Gain R_M has units of Ohms. Ideal: R_in → 0, R_out → 0.

visuals.title: All Four Amplifier Types at a Glance
visuals.description: Comparison of input/output signal types and their associated equivalent circuit models. Each type has unique ideal R_in and R_out requirements.

visuals.title: Loading Effect on Voltage Amplifier
visuals.description: As R_L decreases relative to R_out, the actual output voltage drops below the ideal A_V · V_in. The voltage divider R_L/(R_L + R_out) determines the loss.

visuals.title: Loading Effect on Current Amplifier
visuals.description: For current amplifiers, larger R_out is better — current preferentially flows through R_L when R_out >> R_L.

visuals.title: Ideal Parameters for Each Amplifier Type
visuals.description: Summary: Voltage amp needs R_in=∞, R_out=0. Current amp needs R_in=0, R_out=∞. Transconductance: both ∞. Transresistance: both 0.

visuals.title: Gain Definitions and Units
visuals.description: A_V = V_out/V_in (dimensionless), A_I = I_out/I_in (dimensionless), G_M = I_out/V_in (Siemens), R_M = V_out/I_in (Ohms).

visuals.title: Power Gain: The Universal Requirement
visuals.description: All amplifiers must provide power gain P_out > P_in regardless of whether they amplify voltage, current, or both. Power gain A_P = A_V × A_I.
